elements.content: Four-fold interpenetrating framework 1a can be constructed driven by temperature-controlled SC–SC transformation from 2-fold interpenetrating network 1. Luminescent properties indicated that 1a can be viewed as a luminescent sensor of high-explosives.
elements.clean_text: Four-fold interpenetrating framework 1a can be constructed driven by temperature-controlled SC-SC transformation from 2-fold interpenetrating network 1. Luminescent properties indicated that 1a can be viewed as a luminescent sensor of high-explosives.

elements.content: Four-fold interpenetration framework 1a can be constructed driven by temperature in an SC−SC transformation from 2-fold interpenetration network 1. Luminescent properties indicated that 1a can be viewed as a luminescent sensor of high-explosives.
elements.clean_text: Four-fold interpenetration framework 1a can be constructed driven by temperature in an SC-SC transformation from 2-fold interpenetration network 1. Luminescent properties indicated that 1a can be viewed as a luminescent sensor of high-explosives.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) continue to develop as promising materials in various areas, such as gas separation and storage, catalysis, and sensing, on account of their high surface area and porosity. The well-known tunability of the size, shape, and functional groups of organic linkers connecting metal ions/clusters to gain molecule-based materials provides ample opportunity to tune the properties and applications of such materials. From the perspective of understanding the framework, porosity, stability, and interpenetration, the continued exploration of new structures and novel topologies is greatly important. The design factors such as elaborate modification of the organic linkers, employing secondary building units, and selecting solvents with suitable molecular size have been generally applied as geometric constraints to control interpenetration; temperature-of-reaction-induced interpenetration has not been studied in as great detail. In this communication, we employ a star-like flexible linker, tris­(4-(1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)­phenyl)­amine (TTPA), which results in a structure favoring interpenetration. Through increasing the temperature, a doubly interpenetrated framework {[Co­(TTPA)­(TPA)0.5(H2O)2]·DMA·0.5TPA·H2O} n (1) (TPA = terephthalic acid; DMA = dimethylamine) has been converted into a 4-fold interpenetrating framework {[Co­(TTPA)­(TPA)]·H2O} n (1a) in single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SC–SC) transformation. The result represented here provides a sign that simple but effective means to control the degree of interpenetration in metal–organic framework might come in handy. Such an ability to more precisely control interpenetration is of interest as there are benefits and drawbacks to interpenetration depending on the prospective application: a high interpenetration of structure may be highly thermally stable and display selective recognition of a small-molecule, but it would exhibit a relatively low free volume, therefore limiting applications in areas such as catalysis and separation of macromolecules. However, a comparatively low-interpenetration or even noninterpenetration of structure might allow for a high free volume but incur poor structural stability and an absence of channels to encapsulate small molecules.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) continue to develop as promising materials in various areas, such as gas separation and storage, catalysis, and sensing, on account of their high surface area and porosity. The well-known tunability of the size, shape, and functional groups of organic linkers connecting metal ions/clusters to gain molecule-based materials provides ample opportunity to tune the properties and applications of such materials. From the perspective of understanding the framework, porosity, stability, and interpenetration, the continued exploration of new structures and novel topologies is greatly important. The design factors such as elaborate modification of the organic linkers, employing secondary building units, and selecting solvents with suitable molecular size have been generally applied as geometric constraints to control interpenetration; temperature-of-reaction-induced interpenetration has not been studied in as great detail. In this communication, we employ a star-like flexible linker, tris(4-(1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)phenyl)amine (TTPA), which results in a structure favoring interpenetration. Through increasing the temperature, a doubly interpenetrated framework {[Co(TTPA)(TPA)0.5(H2O)2]⋅DMA⋅0.5TPA⋅H2O} n  (1) (TPA = terephthalic acid; DMA = dimethylamine) has been converted into a 4-fold interpenetrating framework {[Co(TTPA)(TPA)]⋅H2O} n  (1a) in single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SC-SC) transformation. The result represented here provides a sign that simple but effective means to control the degree of interpenetration in metal-organic framework might come in handy. Such an ability to more precisely control interpenetration is of interest as there are benefits and drawbacks to interpenetration depending on the prospective application: a high interpenetration of structure may be highly thermally stable and display selective recognition of a small-molecule, but it would exhibit a relatively low free volume, therefore limiting applications in areas such as catalysis and separation of macromolecules. However, a comparatively low-interpenetration or even noninterpenetration of structure might allow for a high free volume but incur poor structural stability and an absence of channels to encapsulate small molecules.

elements.content: The evaporation at room temperature of TTPA, Co­(OAc)2·4H2O, and TPA in a H2O/CH3OH/DMF mixed solution afforded light purple rod crystals of complex 1 with 40% yield based on TTPA. The crystal structure determination reveals that complex 1 crystallizes in the triclinic crystal system of P1̅. The asymmetric unit contains one Co2+ ion, one TTPA ligand, one TPA2– ligand, three water molecules, and one free dimethylamine molecule. For one star-like ligand TTPA, there is a 3-fold axis at the central N atoms, and it coordinates to three Co atoms through the three triazole groups. Each Co2+ ion is six-coordinated to three Ntriazole atoms, one oxygen atom from the TPA2– ligand and two water molecules, adopting a CoN3O3 distorted octahedral coordination sphere (a). The dihedral angles between the benzene and triazole rings in 1 are 7.2, 19.7, and 38.2°, respectively, thus indicating a different spatial-distortion effect to provide the curvature required for coordination with the CoII ions and dictate the direction of framework extension. As shown in b, alternate linkages of CoII centers and TTPA ligands forms a 1D ladder-like chain, which further leads to a puckered layer through TPA2– ligands. It is noted that there are two kinds of windows among the layer. The rhombic window is composed of two Co centers and two TTPA ligands with dimensions of 15.91 × 11.17 Å2. However, the rectangular one is constituted by four Co centers, two TTPA ligands and two TPA ligands with dimensions of 17.85 × 15.78 Å2. From the viewpoint of topology, the layer of 1 reveals a (3,4)-connected V2O5 topology, in which both the Co center and TTPA ligand act as 4- and 3-connected nodes, respectively, and the TPA ligand is regarded as a linker. Topological analysis reveals that the Schläfli symbol of the layer of 1 can be defined as {42.63.8}­{42.6}. Interestingly, the corrugated nature of such a layer originating from the triangular TTPA results in interpenetration in pairs, as depicted in c. The rectangle and rhombic windows in the same layer are respectively penetrated by the rhombic windows and the TPA ligands from the pairing layer, giving rise to a 2D + 2D → 2D 2-fold interdigitated layer. The two sets of layers and ladders oriented toward different directions and catenated to each other in a parallel–parallel arrangement to form a 2D + 2D → 2D inclined polycatenation structure. There is no direct covalent interaction between interpenetrated layers, and structural stability is kept by weak intermolecular interactions. As exhibited in d, the free TPA ligands as guest molecules are located in the voids of the stacking layers.

Each Co2+ ion is six-coordinated to three Ntriazole atoms, one oxygen atom from the TPA2- ligand and two water molecules, adopting a CoN3O3 distorted octahedral coordination sphere (a). The dihedral angles between the benzene and triazole rings in 1 are 7.2, 19.7, and 38.2°, respectively, thus indicating a different spatial-distortion effect to provide the curvature required for coordination with the CoII ions and dictate the direction of framework extension. As shown in b, alternate linkages of CoII centers and TTPA ligands forms a 1D ladder-like chain, which further leads to a puckered layer through TPA2- ligands. There is no direct covalent interaction between interpenetrated layers, and structural stability is kept by weak intermolecular interactions. As exhibited in d, the free TPA ligands as guest molecules are located in the voids of the stacking layers.

elements.content: (a) View of the coordination environment of CoII and TTPA ligands in 1. (b) Two kinds of linkages in the 2D layer displaying windows with different sizes. (c) View of 2-fold interpenetrating thick layer along b axis. (d) The free TPA and DMA molecules are located in the void of interlayers.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) View of the coordination environment of CoII and TTPA ligands in 1. (b) Two kinds of linkages in the 2D layer displaying windows with different sizes. (c) View of 2-fold interpenetrating thick layer along b axis. (d) The free TPA and DMA molecules are located in the void of interlayers.

elements.content: Encouraged by the aforementioned progress in the study of SC–SC transformations, to study the temperature affects on interpenetration, complex 1 was immersed into H2O and heated to 50 °C for 6 h. This yielded purple rod-shaped crystals of 1a were suitable for X-ray diffraction. We report here that increasing the temperature may increase control over the degree of network interpenetration based on triazole ligands. The crystal structure determination reveals that complex 1a crystallizes in triclinic crystal system of P1̅. The asymmetric unit contains one crystallographically independent Co2+ ion, one TTPA ligand, one deprotonated TPA, and one water molecule (a). The Co1 ion is situated in the center of a distorted octahedral environment with two axial nitrogen atoms from two TPA ligands. The four equatorial atoms are an arrangement of three oxygen atoms from three TTPA ligands and one Ntriazole atom. The Co–O bond lengths are in the range of 2.014(3)–2.311(3) Å, while the Co–N distances vary from 2.111(3) to 2.175(3) Å. The corresponding dihedral angles between the benzene and triazole rings in 1a are 2.1, 6.9, and 43.1°, much less than that of two terminal triazole groups (76.6°). The functional groups are twisted with regard to the central benzene and triaozle rings of TPPT, with torsion angles ranging from 3.4(5)° to 36.3(4)°. As demonstrated in b, each TTPA ligand links three Co1 atoms, serving to play the role of a 3-connecting node to form a 1D ladder-like chain. Noteworthily, two TPAs present two coordination modes: mode I and mode II (Figure S1). In mode I, the carboxylate groups adopt the bidentate chelation, whereas in mode II, only one O atom coordinates to the Co2+ ion. TPA2– ligands in the manner of mode I connect adjacent parallel 1D chains to form a wave-like layer (c), and such layers are further linked together by the other mode of TPA2– ligands to result in a distinct 3D framework (d). Interestingly, there are hexagonal channels with a cross-section of approximately 25 × 17 Å2 along the [111] direction (e). And the large channels allow interpenetration with each other compared to that in 1, finally leaving a 4-fold 3D interpenetrating framework (f). Since the interwoven structures exhibit a smaller pore size compared to their parent noninterpenetrated forms, the potential free volume of the channel after removing the guest molecules is 79.8 Å3 per unit cell volume (1493.9 Å3) calculated by PLATON, which represents only 5.3% of available void space in the unit cell. The Co centers and TTPA ligands can be considered as five and three-connected nodes, indicating that the topology of 1a is AFUQOH with the Schläfli symbol of {42.65.83}­{42.6}.

This yielded purple rod-shaped crystals of 1a were suitable for X-ray diffraction. We report here that increasing the temperature may increase control over the degree of network interpenetration based on triazole ligands. The crystal structure determination reveals that complex 1a crystallizes in triclinic crystal system of P1̅. The asymmetric unit contains one crystallographically independent Co2+ ion, one TTPA ligand, one deprotonated TPA, and one water molecule (a). The Co1 ion is situated in the center of a distorted octahedral environment with two axial nitrogen atoms from two TPA ligands. The four equatorial atoms are an arrangement of three oxygen atoms from three TTPA ligands and one Ntriazole atom. The Co-O bond lengths are in the range of 2.014(3)-2.311(3) Å, while the Co-N distances vary from 2.111(3) to 2.175(3) Å. The corresponding dihedral angles between the benzene and triazole rings in 1a are 2.1, 6.9, and 43.1°, much less than that of two terminal triazole groups (76.6°). The functional groups are twisted with regard to the central benzene and triaozle rings of TPPT, with torsion angles ranging from 3.4(5)° to 36.3(4)°. As demonstrated in b, each TTPA ligand links three Co1 atoms, serving to play the role of a 3-connecting node to form a 1D ladder-like chain. Noteworthily, two TPAs present two coordination modes: mode I and mode II (Figure S1). In mode I, the carboxylate groups adopt the bidentate chelation, whereas in mode II, only one O atom coordinates to the Co2+ ion. TPA2- ligands in the manner of mode I connect adjacent parallel 1D chains to form a wave-like layer (c), and such layers are further linked together by the other mode of TPA2- ligands to result in a distinct 3D framework (d). Interestingly, there are hexagonal channels with a cross-section of approximately 25 × 17 Å2 along the [111] direction (e). And the large channels allow interpenetration with each other compared to that in 1, finally leaving a 4-fold 3D interpenetrating framework (f). Since the interwoven structures exhibit a smaller pore size compared to their parent noninterpenetrated forms, the potential free volume of the channel after removing the guest molecules is 79.8 Å3 per unit cell volume (1493.9 Å3) calculated by PLATON, which represents only 5.3% of available void space in the unit cell. elements.content: (a) View of the coordination environment of CoII and TTPA ligands in 1a. (b) View of the ladder-like chain along a axis. (c) 2D layer constructed from TPA2– ligands and chains. (d) View of the 3D framework of 1a. (e) Space-filling drawing of the channels along [111] direction. (f) View of 4-fold interpenetrating 3D architecture of 1a.

elements.content: The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) curves (Figure S5) show that the guests and coordinated water molecules are removed in the temperature range 20–200 °C for 1. At 353 °C, the coordination networks of 1 begin to decompose. Above 420 °C, the 2-fold interpenetrating framework of 1 collapses because the organic ligands have been removed. However, the 4-fold interpenetrating network of 1a decomposes completely at 436 °C, higher than that of 1. Through careful analysis, 1 tends to be preferred at lower temperatures than 1a, and the character of temperature in regulating interpenetration can be rationalized as it stands to reason that higher temperatures would be predicted to generate a more thermodynamically stable and more densely interpenetrated crystalline state. The increase in dimensionality and interpenetration of the structures of MOF leads to higher degradation temperatures.
elements.clean_text: The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) curves (Figure S5) show that the guests and coordinated water molecules are removed in the temperature range 20-200 °C for 1. At 353 °C, the coordination networks of 1 begin to decompose. Above 420 °C, the 2-fold interpenetrating framework of 1 collapses because the organic ligands have been removed. However, the 4-fold interpenetrating network of 1a decomposes completely at 436 °C, higher than that of 1. Through careful analysis, 1 tends to be preferred at lower temperatures than 1a, and the character of temperature in regulating interpenetration can be rationalized as it stands to reason that higher temperatures would be predicted to generate a more thermodynamically stable and more densely interpenetrated crystalline state. The increase in dimensionality and interpenetration of the structures of MOF leads to higher degradation temperatures.

elements.content: As depicted in Figure S2, TTPA in DMF at room temperature is luminescent and exhibits a broad cyan emission λem,max = 485 nm (λex = 340 nm). In comparison with TTPA, complexes 1 and 1a exhibit blue shifts, as illustrated in Figure S3. They present relatively strong blue and violet fluorescence emission bands at λ = 470 and 443 nm, respectively. It is neither ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) nor metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT). It can probably be appointed to intraligand fluorescent emission due to the same emission shape of the TTPA ligand. The increase of intraligand fluorescence in 1a perhaps accounts for the coordination of TTPA to CoII, which enhances the conformation stiffness of TTPA and decreases the nonradiative decay of the intraligand (π–π*) excited state.
elements.clean_text: As depicted in Figure S2, TTPA in DMF at room temperature is luminescent and exhibits a broad cyan emission λem,max = 485 nm (λex = 340 nm). In comparison with TTPA, complexes 1 and 1a exhibit blue shifts, as illustrated in Figure S3. They present relatively strong blue and violet fluorescence emission bands at λ = 470 and 443 nm, respectively. It is neither ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) nor metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT). It can probably be appointed to intraligand fluorescent emission due to the same emission shape of the TTPA ligand. The increase of intraligand fluorescence in 1a perhaps accounts for the coordination of TTPA to CoII, which enhances the conformation stiffness of TTPA and decreases the nonradiative decay of the intraligand (π-π*) excited state.

elements.content: 2,4,6-Trinitrotoluene (TNT), cyclotrimethylenetrinitramine (CTT), and 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP) are common components of industrial explosives still present in a lot of unexploded ordnance scattered around the world. The detection of such nitro explosives is crucial for environmental monitoring near ordnance stockpiles. Current high-explosive detection methods include canines or sophisticated instruments that are expensive and have portability issues during limited field use. Fluorescence-based detection is gaining increasing attention owing to its high sensitivity, simplicity, short response time, and ability to be employed both in solution and in the solid phase. A lot of π-electron-rich fluorescent conjugated polymers have been synthesized and are used in the detection of trace amounts of nitro aromatics. To further investigate the sensing properties of 1a, the emissive response is monitored by gradually increasing TNT, CTT, and TNP contents of the emulsions of 1a. As shown in and Figure S4, the emission intensity decreased upon the addition of 1 ppm TNT, CTT, and TNP. The luminescence intensity was nearly completely quenched at a concentration of 50 ppm with a high quenching efficiency of 98.9, 99.0, and 99.5%, respectively, which is comparable to other MOF sensors for TNP and TNT.
elements.clean_text: 2,4,6-Trinitrotoluene (TNT), cyclotrimethylenetrinitramine (CTT), and 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP) are common components of industrial explosives still present in a lot of unexploded ordnance scattered around the world. The detection of such nitro explosives is crucial for environmental monitoring near ordnance stockpiles. Current high-explosive detection methods include canines or sophisticated instruments that are expensive and have portability issues during limited field use. Fluorescence-based detection is gaining increasing attention owing to its high sensitivity, simplicity, short response time, and ability to be employed both in solution and in the solid phase. A lot of π-electron-rich fluorescent conjugated polymers have been synthesized and are used in the detection of trace amounts of nitro aromatics. To further investigate the sensing properties of 1a, the emissive response is monitored by gradually increasing TNT, CTT, and TNP contents of the emulsions of 1a. As shown in  and Figure S4, the emission intensity decreased upon the addition of 1 ppm TNT, CTT, and TNP. The luminescence intensity was nearly completely quenched at a concentration of 50 ppm with a high quenching efficiency of 98.9, 99.0, and 99.5%, respectively, which is comparable to other MOF sensors for TNP and TNT.

elements.content: Effect on the emission spectra of 1a dispersed in DMF upon incremental addition of a CTT solution.
elements.clean_text: 3  Effect on the emission spectra of 1a dispersed in DMF upon incremental addition of a CTT solution.

elements.content: In addition, different anions were employed to carry out the anion-sensing function according to the porosity of 1. Various aqueous solutions of anions, for example, SO4 2–, CO3 2–, PO4 3–, F–, NO3 –, BF4 –, Cl–, Br–, OAc–, NO2 –, I–, ClO4 –, and MnO4 –, were used to immerse the sample of 1. The luminescent properties indicate that various anions have a significant impact on the luminescent intensity of 1. Notably, MnO4 – has the greatest quenching effect on the luminescent emission, and the intensity approaches zero (Figure S5). MnO4 – may also be absorbed onto the surface of 1. The mechanism of luminescence quenching may be as follows: Luminescent quenching of 1 induced by MnO4 – anions may be ascribed to the interactions between MnO4 – anions and the network. This result occurs due to the competitive adsorption of the excitation wavelength energy between 1 and MnO4 –.
elements.clean_text: In addition, different anions were employed to carry out the anion-sensing function according to the porosity of 1. Various aqueous solutions of anions, for example, SO4 2-, CO3 2-, PO4 3-, F-, NO3 -, BF4 -, Cl-, Br-, OAc-, NO2 -, I-, ClO4 -, and MnO4 -, were used to immerse the sample of 1. The luminescent properties indicate that various anions have a significant impact on the luminescent intensity of 1. Notably, MnO4 - has the greatest quenching effect on the luminescent emission, and the intensity approaches zero (Figure S5). MnO4 - may also be absorbed onto the surface of 1. The mechanism of luminescence quenching may be as follows: Luminescent quenching of 1 induced by MnO4 - anions may be ascribed to the interactions between MnO4 - anions and the network. This result occurs due to the competitive adsorption of the excitation wavelength energy between 1 and MnO4 -.

At 353 °C, the coordination networks of 1 begin to decompose. Above 420 °C, the 2-fold interpenetrating framework of 1 collapses because the organic ligands have been removed. However, the 4-fold interpenetrating network of 1a decomposes completely at 436 °C, higher than that for 1. Through careful analysis, 1 tends to be preferred at lower temperatures than 1a, and the character of temperature in regulating interpenetration can be rationalized as it stands to reason that higher temperatures would be predicted to generate a more thermodynamically stable and more densely interpenetrated crystalline state. The increase in dimensionality and interpenetration of the structures of MOF leads to higher degradation temperatures.

elements.content: In conclusion, the 4-fold interpenetrating framework of 1a can be constructed via temperature induced SC–SC transformation from the 2-fold interpenetrating network of 1. Luminescent properties indicated that 1 and 1a can be viewed as the selective sensors of MnO4 – and high-explosives, respectively.
